{{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = Fukuoka |local = {{lang|ja|カトリック福岡教区}} |latin = Dioecesis Fukuokaensis |image = Daimyomachi Catholic Church.jpg |image_size = 230px |caption = Cathedral of the Diocese |country = {{flag|Japan}} |metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Nagasaki|Nagasaki 長崎]] |province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Nagasaki|Nagasaki 長崎]] |coordinates = {{coord|33|35|N|130|24|E|source:kolossus-plwiki|display=inline,title}} |rite = [[Latin Rite]] |cathedral = Cathedral of Our Lady of Victory in [[Fukuoka]] |cocathedral = |established = 16 July 1927 |area_km2 = 14808 |population = 7,754,937 |population_as_of = 2006 |catholics = 31,289 |catholics_percent= 0.4 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = [[Dominic Ryōji Miyahara]] |metro_archbishop = Joseph Mitsuaki Takami |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= |map = Giappone - Diocesi di Fukuoka.png |website = [http://fukuoka.catholic.jp/ Website of the Diocese] }}
The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Fukuoka''' ({{lang-la|Fukuokaën(sis)}}, {{lang-ja|カトリック福岡教区}}) is a [[diocese]] located in the city of [[Fukuoka, Fukuoka|Fukuoka]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Nagasaki|Nagasaki 長崎]] in Japan.
==History== * July 16, 1927: Established as Diocese of Fukuoka from the Diocese of [[Nagasaki]]
==Leadership== * [[Bishop]]s of Fukuoka ([[Roman Rite]]) *Fernand-Jean-Joseph Thiry, [[Paris Foreign Missions Society|M.E.P.]] † (14 Jul 1927 Appointed - 10 May 1930 Died) *Albert Henri Charles Breton, M.E.P. † (9 Jun 1931 Appointed - 16 Jan 1941 Resigned) *Dominic Senyemon Fukahori † (9 Mar 1944 Appointed - 15 Nov 1969 Retired) *Peter Saburo Hirata, [[Society of Saint-Sulpice|P.S.S.]] † (15 Nov 1969 Appointed - 6 Oct 1990 Retired) *Joseph Hisajiro Matsunaga † (6 Oct 1990 Appointed - 2 Jun 2006 Died) *[[Dominic]] Ryoji Miyahara (19 Mar 2008 Appointed - )
==See also== *[[Roman Catholicism in Japan]]
==Sources== * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/fuku0.htm GCatholic.org] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dfuku.html Catholic Hierarchy]
== External links == * http://www.cbcj.catholic.jp/jpn/diocese/fukuoka.htm

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use British English|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox company | name = STV Group plc | logo = [[File:STV logo 2014.png|175px]] | type = [[Public limited company]] | traded_as = {{LSE|STVG}} | foundation = 1957
(as Scottish Television plc) | location = {{nowrap|[[Glasgow]], Scotland, UK}} | key_people = Simon Pitts (CEO)
Baroness Ford of Cunninghame (Chairman)https://www.stvplc.tv/about-us/board-of-directors | industry = Media | products = [[Television]], [[Internet]] | revenue = [[Pound sterling|£]]117 million (2017){{cite web |url=https://www.stvplc.tv/files/download/d8e337836f012fa |title=Annual Report 2017 |accessdate=15 August 2018 |publisher=STV Group}} | operating_income = {{profit}} £19 million (2017) | net_income = {{profit}} (£11.7 million) (2017) | num_employees = 408 (established staff)
43 (contract) (2017) | homepage = [http://www.stvplc.tv www.stvplc.tv] }} '''STV Group plc''', previously known as '''Scottish Television plc''' and '''Scottish Media Group plc''', is a Scottish media company. It is a constituent of the [[FTSE Fledgling Index]]. Originally formed as [[Scottish Television]], the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] licence holder for central Scotland, the company changed its name to Scottish Media Group in 1996 and acquired the licence holder for Northern Scotland, [[Grampian Television]], in 1997. The Scottish and Grampian channels were rebranded as [[STV (TV channel)|STV]] in 2006. ==History== [[File:SMG PLC New.PNG|thumb|Right|SMG's last logo before rebrand]] [[Scottish Television]] began broadcasting in August 1957. The company changed its name to Scottish Media Group in 1996 when it acquired Caledonian Publishing, owners of Glasgow-based newspapers ''[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]]'' and ''[[Evening Times]]'' (both of which have since been sold). It went on to acquire the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] licence holder for Northern Scotland, [[Grampian Television]] in June 1997.Scottish Media seeks to loosen ties with ITV. Eric Reguly. The Times (London, England), Wednesday, 11 June 1997 In August 1997 the company acquired a 15% stake in [[UTV (TV channel)|UTV]], Northern Ireland.Scottish buys into Ulster TVBuckingham, LisaThe Guardian (1959-2003); 15 Aug 1997 In 1999 it launched a new Sunday broadsheet newspaper, the ''[[Sunday Herald]]''. The company was renamed "SMG plc" in 2000, by which time it had expanded further through the acquisitions of Primesight (outdoor advertising), [[Pearl & Dean]] and Ginger Media Group, which included [[Ginger Television]] and the original [[Absolute Radio|Virgin Radio]] UK radio station.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/601640.stm |title=Evans sells up |publisher=BBC News |date=13 January 2000 |accessdate=2013-06-22}} Talks were also held which could have led to [[ITV Border|Border Television]] and [[UTV (TV channel)|Ulster Television]] being bought, but they came to nothing.{{cite news|last=McIvor |first=Jamie |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/5192488.stm |title=Tongues wag as SMG chief resigns |publisher=BBC News |date=18 July 2006 |accessdate=2013-06-22}} On 24 March 1999, [[Trinity Mirror|Mirror Group]] sold its 18.6% stake in SMG to [[Granada plc|Granada]].{{cite news|last=Larsen |first=Peter Thal |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/granada-stalks-scottish-with-pounds-110m-share-buy-1082697.html |title=Granada stalks Scottish with pounds 110m share buy |work=The Independent |date=24 March 1999 |accessdate=2013-06-22}} During the summer, the STV Group held talks about buying out the other shareholders in GMTV, with [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]] believed to be keen on the idea;{{cite web|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/news/article-1577208/Scots-Media-set-to-buy-GMTV.html |title=Scots Media set to buy GMTV |publisher=This is Money |date=1999-09-01 |accessdate=2013-06-22}}{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/scottish-media-seeks-gmtv-stock-1115743.html |title=Scottish Media seeks GMTV stock |publisher=The Independent |date=1999-09-03 |accessdate=2013-06-22}} many city observers believed this was a defensive move to fend off a takeover bid from Granada. By September an agreement had been reached to acquire Guardian Media Group's 15% stake in [[GMTV]] for £20 million, but both [[Carlton Television|Carlton]] and Granada objected to the deal.{{cite web|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/smg-bid-for-gmtv-stake-could-be-blocked/1219881.article |title=SMG bid for GMTV stake could be blocked |publisher=Broadcast |date=1999-09-10 |accessdate=2013-06-22}} Guardian Media Group eventually sold its stake for £18m in January 2000, but STV Group only acquired 5% with the remaining 10% going to Carlton and Granada, resulting in each of STV Group, Carlton, Granada and Disney holding 25% of GMTV.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2000/sep/05/16 |title=GMTV |work=The Guardian |date=5 September 2000 |accessdate=10 January 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/trio-share-gmtv-stake/1187804.article |title=Trio share GMTV stake |publisher=Broadcast |date=2000-01-07 |accessdate=2013-06-22}} In September 1999, the company acquired a 37.4% stake in [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.]] for £8 million. A few days later the company unveiled its interim results with its pre-tax profits up 2 per cent to £24 million on a turnover of £111.2 million. In December 2000, the group acquired a 14.9% stake in [[Scottish Radio Holdings]], in anticipation of a relaxation of radio ownership rules{{cite news |last=Milmo |first=Dan |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2000/dec/08/citynews.broadcasting |title=Scottish Media Group buys SRH stake |publisher=The Guardian |date=8 December 2000 |accessdate=10 January 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/1061693.stm |title=Shares soar after radio deal |publisher=BBC News |date=8 December 2000 |accessdate=2013-06-22}} and within four months increased this to 27.7%.{{cite web|url=http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/news/13097/Scottish-Media-Group-increases-stake-Scottish-Radio/?DCMP=ILC-SEARCH |title=Scottish Media Group increases stake in Scottish Radio |publisher=Media Week |date=2001-03-07 |accessdate=2013-06-22}} By 2004 the company sold their 27.8% stake in Scottish Radio Holdings to [[Emap|EMAP]] for £90 million in anticipation of consolidation in the radio market.{{cite web|url=http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/news/513362/ |title=Emap buys stake in Scottish Radio Holdings |publisher=Media Week |date=2004-01-19 |accessdate=2013-06-22}} [[Living TV Group|Flextech]] owner Telewest sold its 16.9% stake in STV Group to an investment bank for £45 million as part of their plan to raise funds to help clear off debt.{{cite web|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/news/article-1532419/Telewest-sells-SMG-stake-for-16345m.html |title=Telewest sells SMG stake for £45m |publisher=This is Money |date=2002-11-06 |accessdate=2013-06-22}}{{cite news |last=Milmo |first=Dan |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2002/nov/06/smg.citynews |title=Telewest offloads SMG stake |work=The Guardian |date=6 November 2002 |accessdate=10 January 2016}} Throughout 2003/2004 rumours appeared about the company being broken up, with its ITV interests being sold off in an attempt to wipe out its £380m debt and boost its balance sheet. However, the group instead sold the Herald newspapers and its stake in Scottish Radio Holdings. In late 2003 Northern Ireland's [[UTV Media|UTV]], in partnership with venture capital group [[3i]] and Scottish Radio Holdings, sought to acquire SMG for £400 million, but they withdrew the offer as they felt the share price was too high.{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-24724574.html |title=UTV on the acquisition trail after SMG failure |publisher=HighBeam Research |date=2004-03-16 |accessdate=2013-06-22}}{{cite web|url=http://www.brandrepublic.com/news/204970/Ulster-TV-plots-400m-bid-buy-Scottish-Media-Group/ |title=Ulster TV plots £400m bid to buy Scottish Media Group |publisher=Brand Republic |date=2004-03-15 |accessdate=2013-06-22}} In September 2004, [[ITV plc]] purchased STV Group's 25% stake in GMTV for £31 million,{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2004/may/10/smg.citynews |title=ITV buys GMTV stake from SMG |first=Chris |last=Tryhorn |work=Guardian |date=10 May 2004 |accessdate=10 January 2016}} after being given the go ahead from the [[Office of Fair Trading]], despite advertiser fears it could give ITV influence over pricing.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} SMG said "SMG are pulling out of GMTV because it did not want to hold a minority interest in someone else's media business".{{cite web|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/itv-gets-go-ahead-on-gmtv-shares/1099172.article |title=ITV gets go-ahead on GMTV shares |publisher=Broadcast |date=2004-09-23 |accessdate=2013-06-22}} Andrew Flanagan unexpectedly resigned as chief executive in July 2006. Although he helped create the company since 1998, his spell in charge will be remembered by many in the television industry as a period which saw a dramatic decline in the amount of programmes made by the company for transmission within Scotland alone. Rob Woodward became the new chief executive in 2007, and started a major reconstruction of the group by instigating a sell-off of poorly performing assets,{{cite web|last=Hobson |first=Ben |url=http://www.stockopedia.co.uk/content/rob-woodward-of-scottish-media-group-stv-talks-to-stockopedia-47078/ |title=Rob Woodward Of Scottish Media Group STV Talks To Stockopedia |publisher=Stockopedia |date=2010-09-01 |accessdate=2013-06-22}} starting with Primesight being sold for £62m to a private equity firm.{{cite news | title = Primesight auction halted as SMG seeks better price | publisher = prweek.com | date = 17 April 2007 | url = http://www.prweek.com/uk/news/650863/Primesight-auction-halted-SMG-seeks-better-price/?DCMP=ILC-SEARCH | accessdate = 6 March 2013}}{{cite news | title = http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/news/731315/ | publisher = media week | date = 14 August 2007 | url = http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/news/731315/ | accessdate = 6 March 2013}}{{cite news | title = SMG to spin off Virgin Radio as earnings fall |first=Jin |last=Stanton | work = Edinburgh Evening News | date = 12 April 2007 | url = http://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/news/smg-to-spin-off-virgin-radio-as-earnings-fall-1-1201367 | accessdate = 10 January 2016}} SMG said in a statement that the price GMT Communications Partners paid represented a "clear uplift" on offers previously received for Primesight.{{cite news | title = Proposed disposal of Primesight | publisher = London Stock Exchange | date = 31 August 2007 | url = http://www.investegate.co.uk/article.aspx?id=200708310701470633D | accessdate = 6 March 2013}} Primesight have been prosecuted a number of times for the display of advertisements without consent which is an offence under UK Planning Acts.{{cite news |title = Company fined for illegal advertising |publisher = Wandsworth Council |date = 30 May 2007 |url = http://ww3.wandsworth.gov.uk/news/pressreleasedetail.asp?id=5061 |accessdate = 6 March 2013 |archive-url = https://archive.is/20130423185242/http://ww3.wandsworth.gov.uk/news/pressreleasedetail.asp?id=5061# |archive-date = 23 April 2013 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}{{cite news|title=It all ads up to a £6k fine |publisher=This is Local London |date=7 June 2007 |url=http://www.thisislocallondon.com/whereilive/localheadlines/display.var.1454962.0.it_all_ads_up_to_a_6k_fine.php |accessdate=27 November 2007 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} The lack of consent for many of Primesight's displays is said to have reduced the selling price by up to £30 million.{{cite news | title = Hindsight on SMG's sale of Primesight | publisher = Sunday Herald | year = 2007 | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-10019055.html | accessdate = 6 March 2013}} Further major changes occurred when STV Group sold Virgin Radio to a group led by [[The Times of India]] on 31 May 2008.{{cite news | title = Virgin Radio sold to Indian group | publisher = BBC News | date = 31 May 2008 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/7429193.stm | accessdate = 31 May 2008}} In June 2008, SMG plc announced plans to change its name to ''STV Group plc''. The company said the proposed name change was to highlight its renewed focus on television, encompassing the [[Scottish Television|STV Central]] and [[Grampian Television|STV North]] franchises, as well as the company's TV production business.{{cite news | title = SMG reborn as STV Group | publisher = The Guardian | date = 24 June 2008 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/jun/24/mediabusiness.television | accessdate = 10 January 2016 | first=Caitlin | last=Fitzsimmons}} This name change was approved at an [[extraordinary general meeting]] in September 2008, along with a new deal resulting in Pearl & Dean handling advertising for [[Showcase Cinemas]], which meant that the Pearl & Dean titles would appear in just under half of UK cinema sites.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/7631338.stm |title=Scottish media group changes name |publisher=BBC News |date=23 September 2008 |accessdate=2013-06-22}} The new ''STV Group'' branding was introduced on 1 October 2008.{{cite news | title = Goodbye SMG... Hello STV Group | publisher = BroadcastNow | date = 1 October 2008 | url = http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/2008/10/goodbye_smg_hello_stv_group.html | accessdate = 2 October 2008}} By 2010 the group had sold off all non-television assets, including selling cinema advertising company Pearl & Dean for £1 to Image Ltd, a newly formed company backed by [[Empire Cinemas]] director Thomas Anderson, with STV still recouping £9.1m from the business due to a 2010 payment from [[Vue Cinemas]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/8634158.stm |title=STV to sell Pearl & Dean for £1 |publisher=BBC News |date=21 April 2010 |accessdate=2013-06-22}} This action helped reduce the group's debt and allowed it to concentrate on its core television businesses. As a result of this, STV Group largely reverted to its Scottish Television plc days, but with the addition of the former Grampian Television and Ginger Productions businesses (the latter retained from the Ginger Media acquisition). ===Merger proposals=== In September 2006, STV Group (then SMG) officially rejected a merger offer from Northern Irish ITV franchise holder [[UTV Media|UTV]]. The merger approach would have given SMG shareholders a 52% stake in the combined company. The Scottish group said its board had examined a revised merger proposal from UTV, but did not believe it reflected the value of the company.{{cite news | title = SMG turns down UTV merger bid | work = The Guardian | date = 29 August 2006 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2006/aug/29/smg.radio | accessdate = 10 January 2016 | first=Julia | last=Day}} In 2006 [[ITV plc]] considered making an offer for STV Group, according to ''[[The Mail on Sunday]]''. The newspaper quoted an ITV source as saying John Cresswell, acting chief executive at the broadcaster, was most interested in the group's television franchises, but that any deal would have been for the whole group. SMG warned that its 2006 profit would be materially behind expectations, sending its shares down more than a quarter in value to a 15-year low.{{cite news | title = ITV mulls bid for media firm SMG | publisher = The Scotsman | date = 29 October 2006 | url = http://business.scotsman.com/latest.cfm?id=1600952006 | accessdate = 7 March 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061101124527/http://business.scotsman.com/latest.cfm?id=1600952006 |archivedate = 1 November 2006}} On 10 January 2007, SMG and UTV agreed details of a merger, including a revised share split between the two. UTV would own 54% of the group, with SMG owning the remaining 46%.{{cite news |title = UTV gains ground in SMG merger negotiations |publisher = The Business |date = 10 January 2007 |url = http://www.thebusinessonline.com/Document.aspx?id=F1FE66B5-A1D6-414C-B350-94E0A5342A2F |accessdate = 7 March 2007 }}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} This merger was finally rejected at the end of February 2007, and a new board and management team were introduced at SMG shortly afterwards. ===Relationship with ITV plc=== STV Group plc has had a turbulent relationship with [[ITV plc]] and both [[Carlton Television|Carlton]] and [[ITV Granada|Granada]], the predecessor companies that merged to create it. ITV plc owns the ITV franchises in [[England]], [[Northern Ireland]], [[Wales]], Southern Scotland ([[Dumfries and Galloway]] and the [[Scottish Borders]]), the [[Isle of Man]] and the [[Channel Islands]]. ITV plc also operates a number of digital channels and websites under the ITV brand. The company threatened to take legal action over the use of the name 'ITV' because it is the name of the Independent Television network, which [[Scottish Television|STV Central]] and [[Grampian Television|STV North]] are both part of. One of the problems facing the group is that ITV is the senior partner when it comes to its two TV stations, since London-based ITV effectively controls most of the scheduling and is also responsible for selling STV's advertising airtime.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} In September 2009, ITV plc announced it was to launch legal proceedings against STV for a claimed unpaid debt of £38 million from network programming contributions, following STV's practice of dropping a number of network programmes on the STV franchise. At the same time, STV claimed it was also following procedures against ITV plc, for up to £40 million owed to STV under its advertising sales agreements.{{cite news | title = ITV takes legal action over STV's network programme payments | publisher = The Guardian | date = 22 September 2009 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/sep/22/itv-stv-network-programme-budget-contributions | accessdate = 10 January 2016 | first=Leigh | last=Holmwood}} ==Television== ===STV=== {{main|STV (TV channel)}} STV Group plc owns two Scottish ITV licences: [[Scottish Television]], which covers Central Scotland, and [[Grampian Television]], covering Northern Scotland. On 2 March 2006, it was announced that Scottish Television would revert to using its former brand name of "STV", which it previously used from the start of colour broadcasting in 1969 until 30 August 1985, and which the station was still informally known as in parts of Scotland. Scottish Television became known as ''STV Central''. At the same time, Grampian Television would also become known as ''STV North'', with the one main identity of ''STV'' serving the two licences. The rebrand took place on 30 May 2006. ====Other channels==== The former SMG plc ran its own digital channel, [[S2 (TV channel)|S2]], throughout the Scottish and Grampian ITV regions. S2, which aired on the Digital Terrestrial platform, was launched on 30 April 1999 and was replaced by [[ITV2]] just over two years later – as part of a deal with [[ITV Digital]] – on 27 July 2001.{{cite news | title = S2 dropped for ITV2 | publisher = Digital Spy | date = 27 July 2001 | url = http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/digitaltv/a3459/s2-dropped-for-itv2.html | accessdate = 31 August 2007}} [[Sky Scottish]] was a satellite television channel operating on the analogue Sky TV service between 1 November 1996 and 31 May 1998. The service was a joint venture between [[BSkyB|British Sky Broadcasting]] and SMG. It initially broadcast between 6.00pm and 8.00pm. The channel was closed due to poor ratings.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} A high-definition channel, [[STV (TV network)#STV HD|STV HD]], launched on 6 June 2010.{{cite news|url=http://www.stv.tv/stvhd|title=HD television is coming to STV|publisher=STV (TV network)|accessdate=1 June 2010}} On 11 January 2013, STV were awarded two [[Local television in the United Kingdom|local TV licences]] by [[Ofcom]] to operate digital terrestrial television channels in Glasgow and Edinburgh for up to 12 years.{{cite web|url=http://media.ofcom.org.uk/2013/01/11/ofcom-awards-local-tv-licences-in-scotland/|title=Ofcom awards local TV licences in Scotland|publisher=[[Ofcom]]|date=11 January 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105143144/http://media.ofcom.org.uk/2013/01/11/ofcom-awards-local-tv-licences-in-scotland/|archivedate=5 November 2013|df=dmy-all}} The two channels, [[STV Glasgow]] and [[STV Edinburgh]], were to be delivered in partnership with [[Glasgow Caledonian University]] and [[Edinburgh Napier University]] respectively.{{cite news|url=http://news.stv.tv/scotland/209292-stv-awarded-local-television-licences-for-glasgow-and-edinburgh/|title=STV awarded local television licences for Glasgow and Edinburgh|work=STV|date=11 January 2013 |accessdate=10 January 2016}} STV Glasgow launched on 2 June 2014,{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-26817726 |title=STV Glasgow digital TV channel June launch date |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=31 March 2014}} and STV Edinburgh launched on 12 January 2015. In March 2015, STV were awarded local licences for the Aberdeen, Ayr and Dundee areas.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ofcom.org.uk/about-ofcom/latest/media/media-releases/2015/aberdeen-ayr-dundee|title=Ofcom announces local TV licences for Aberdeen, Ayr and Dundee|date=19 March 2015|website=Ofcom|language=en|access-date=8 June 2017}} In April 2017, STV Glasgow and STV Edinburgh were re-branded as [[STV2]]. Just over a year later in May 2018, STV announced that it would be closing STV2 on 30 June 2018.https://stv.tv/news/scotland/1415173-stv-to-close-stv2-channel-as-broadcaster-cuts-59-jobs/ ==Production== ===STV Productions=== {{main|STV Productions}} STV Productions (renamed from SMG Productions on 1 October 2008) forms part of the network television production arm of STV Group plc, producing drama, factual, entertainment and children's output from its bases in Glasgow and London for all UK terrestrial networks as well as key satellite and cable channels. ===Ginger Productions=== {{main|Ginger Productions}} Ginger Productions (founded by the presenter [[Chris Evans (presenter)|Chris Evans]]), alongside STV Productions, is part of the network production arm of STV Group plc. Based in [[Waterhouse Square]] in London, its output focuses on Entertainment and Factual Entertainment. Ginger was acquired as part of SMG's acquisition of the Ginger Media Group in 1999. ===STV Creative=== STV Creative is the company's commercial production division, based in [[Glasgow]]. ===Solutions=== Solutions is STV's production resources division, providing facilities for studios, outside broadcasts, post-production, corporate events and commercial productions. ==Internet== ===stv.tv=== The URL [[stv.tv]] is the address of the main website of STV. The website currently offers News, Sport, Weather, Entertainment, Competitions, and STV programme information, and TV listings. ===STV Cities=== STV Cities is a Scottish network of hyper-local, community-based websites and [[mobile app]]s. Pilot sites were launched in Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, Edinburgh, Moray and North & South Lanarkshire.{{when|date=December 2014}} In October 2013 STV launched apps, accompanied by a website, for Aberdeen, Edinburgh, Dundee and Glasgow.{{cite news|url=http://news.stv.tv/scotland/244847-stv-launches-new-digital-services-for-scotlands-biggest-cities/ |title=STV launches new digital services for Scotland's biggest cities |publisher=STV News |date=22 October 2013}} ===STV Player=== [[STV Player]] is the video section of the main stv.tv website. It offers catchup of regular STV programming, along with archive STV programmes and exclusive videos. ===STV Bingo=== STV Bingo was launched in 2006 and is run in partnership with CashCade. ==Studios== STV Group's headquarters in Glasgow are based at Pacific Quay, a development situated next to the River Clyde, in July 2006, alongside [[BBC Scotland]]'s new studios and the [[Glasgow Science Centre]]. STV Group's Aberdeen studios moved to a new purpose-built site in the city's Tullos area in 2003, from their previous location (a converted tram shed), which they occupied since Grampian launched in 1961.{{cite news |title = SMG begins move to brand new home at Pacific Quay |publisher = SMG Television |date = 7 July 2006 |url = http://stv.lumison.net/content/default.asp?page=s5_4_4&newsid=3492 |accessdate = 31 August 2007 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} STV also has studios in Edinburgh, Dundee and Inverness providing regional news coverage in their particular area. ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {| border="0" style="width:100%; vertical-align:top;" |- | style="vertical-align:top; text-align:left; width:33%;"| *[http://www.stvplc.tv STV Group plc] *[http://www.stv.tv STV] | style="vertical-align:top; text-align:left; width:33%;"| *[http://www.stvcreative.tv STV Creative] *[http://www.stvproductions.tv STV Productions] | style="vertical-align:top; text-align:left; width:33%;"| *[http://www.stv.tv/bingo STV Bingo] *{{Twitter|name=STV Press}} | style="vertical-align:top; text-align:left; width:25%;"| |} {{STV Group plc}} {{Navboxes|list1= {{ITV}} {{Absolute Radio}} {{Media in the United Kingdom|comporg}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stv Group Plc}} [[Category:1957 establishments in Scotland]] [[Category:Companies based in Glasgow]] [[Category:Media companies of Scotland]] [[Category:Media in Glasgow]] [[Category:Media in Scotland]] [[Category:STV Group plc| ]] [[Category:Television in Scotland]] [[Category:Virgin Radio (UK)]] [[Category:British companies established in 1957]] [[Category:Media companies established in 1957]]

{{Time zones of Europe}} '''European Summer Time''' is the variation of standard clock time that is applied in most [[Europe]]an countries (not including [[Iceland]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Azerbaijan]], [[Belarus]], [[Turkey]] and [[Russia]]) in the period between spring and autumn, during which clocks are advanced by one hour from the time observed in the rest of the year, in order to make the most efficient use of seasonal daylight. It corresponds to the notion and practice of [[daylight saving time]] to be found in many other parts of the world.
European Summer Time begins at 01:00 [[UTC]]/[[Western European Time|WET]] (02:00 [[Central European Time|CET]], 03:00 [[Eastern European Time|EET]]) on the last Sunday in March and ends at 01:00 UTC (02:00 [[Western European Summer Time|WEST]], 03:00 [[Central European Summer Time|CEST]], 04:00 [[Eastern European Summer Time|EEST]]) on the last Sunday in October each year; i.e. the change is made at the same absolute time across all time zones. [[European Union]] Directive 2000/84/EC makes summer time mandatory for EU member states (except overseas territories), though a proposal to repeal this directive and require member states to observe (their own choice of) an unchanging time year-round, is currently going through the legislative process.
Summer Time lasts, depending upon the calendar year, for either 30 or 31 weeks of the year.
==History== Summer Time was first introduced during the [[First World War]]. However, most countries discontinued the practice after the war. It was then restarted in various countries during the [[Second World War]] and its immediate aftermath. Again it was widely cancelled by the 1950s, but reintroduced in isolated cases until the late 1960s, when the energy crisis began to prompt policymakers to reintroduce Summer Time across the continent. It has remained in place in most European countries since then.
Historically the countries of Europe had different practices for observing Summer Time, but this hindered coordination of transport, communications and movements. Starting in 1981 the [[European Commission]] began issuing [[European Union directive|directives]] requiring member states to legislate harmonised start and end dates for Summer Time.<ref name=Report>{{cite web|title=Communication from the commission to the Council, the European Parliament and the European economic and social committee under Article 5 of Directive 2000/84/EC on summer time arrangements|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=COM:2007:0739:FIN:EN:NOT|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=8 March 2015|date=23 November 2007}}</ref>
Since 1981 each directive has specified a transition time of 01:00 UTC and a start date of the last Sunday in March, but the end dates have differed. Successive Directives laid down two dates for the end: one on the last Sunday in September applied by the continental Member States, and the other on the fourth Sunday in October for the United Kingdom and Ireland.<ref name=Report/> In 1996 the end date was changed to the fourth Sunday in October for all countries.<ref>{{cite web|title=European Commission - Mobility and Transport: Summertime|url=http://ec.europa.eu/transport/summertime_en.htm|date=24 October 2014}}</ref> In 1998 the end date was changed to the last Sunday in October; this happened to be the same as the previous rule for 1996 and 1997.<ref>{{cite web|title=History of legal time in Britain|author=Joseph Myers|url=http://www.srcf.ucam.org/~jsm28/british-time/|date=21 January 2007|accessdate=24 March 2007}}</ref> The ninth directive, Directive 2000/84/EC, currently (2018) in force, specifies this rule.<ref name=EC>{{cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:32000L0084:EN:NOT|title=Directive 2000/84/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 19 January 2001 on summer time arrangement}}</ref>
==Future== There were proposals in 2015 and 2016 from members of the [[European Parliament]] to abolish summer time observance, but the [[European Commission]] did not at that time put forward proposals to be considered, saying it had not found conclusive evidence in favour of a change, and [[Member State of the European Union|member states]] were divided. It did however note that a cost would be incurred if harmonisation between member states' summer time rules was lost.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://epthinktank.eu/2016/03/24/summertime-changing-the-clocks/|title=Summertime: changing the clocks|author=|date=24 March 2016|website=epthinktank.eu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.timeanddate.com/news/time/eu-dst-discussions.html|title=EU Politicians Speak Up to Remove DST|author=|date=|website=www.timeanddate.com}}</ref> In 2017 the Finnish and Lithuanian parliaments both voted in favour of proposals calling on the EU to reconsider daylight saving, with similar criticism from Poland and Sweden. The European Commission at the time was reviewing the practice.<ref>[https://www.euractiv.com/section/health-consumers/news/finland-wants-eu-to-give-up-daylight-saving-time/ Finland wants EU to give up daylight saving time], Euractiv 27/10/17</ref><ref>[http://www.euractiv.com/section/health-consumers/news/lithuania-hopes-to-kill-daylight-savings-time/ Lithuania hopes to kill daylight savings time], Euractiv 22/11/17</ref>
On 8 February 2018, the European Parliament voted to ask the European Commission to re-evaluate DST in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.timeanddate.com/news/time/eu-parliament-abolish-dst.html|title=EU Parliament Votes to Re-Evaluate DST in Europe|author=|date=|website=www.timeanddate.com}}</ref> After a web survey showing high support for not switching clocks twice annually,<ref>[http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-18-5302_en.htm Summertime Consultation: 84% want Europe to stop changing the clock]</ref> on 12 September 2018 the European Commission decided to propose that an end be put to seasonal clock changes (repealing Directive 2000/84/EC).<ref>[http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_MEMO-18-5641_en.htm State of the Union 2018: Q&A on the Commission's proposal to put an end to seasonal clock changes] European Commission − Press Release (Strasbourg, 12 September 2018)</ref> In order for this to be valid, the [[European Union legislative procedure]] must be followed, mainly that the [[Council of the European Union]] and the European Parliament must both approve the proposal.
Under the proposal, member countries are expected to decide by 31 March 2019 whether they wish to retain their current winter time year round{{snd}} in which case they would change clocks for the last time in October 2019, or their current summer time{{snd}} in which case the last change would be in March 2019. This is however considered a fairly tight timescale by many.<ref name=resistjuncker/><ref name=bbc-Clock-ticking/> The [[Internet Assigned Numbers Authority]], which coordinates changes to the [[tz database|time zone database]] used by most computers and smartphones, notes that "With less than a year's notice there is a good chance that some computer-based clocks will operate incorrectly after the change, due to delays in propagating updates to software and data."<ref>{{cite web |title=Sources for time zone and daylight saving time data |url=https://data.iana.org/time-zones/tz-link.html#changes |website=data.iana.org |publisher=IANA |accessdate=24 October 2018 |language=en}}</ref> The airline industry points out the complexity of revising all airline schedules, particularly in terms of ensuring slot availability on flights outside the EU, and recommends keeping the status quo or deferring the change until at least 2021.<ref>{{cite web |title=Joint industry position on Summertime Arrangements |url=https://www.iata.org/policy/slots/Documents/Position%20papers/Airlines-Position-on-European-Summertime%20Arrangements.pdf |website=www.iata.org |publisher=IATA |accessdate=28 October 2018 |language=en-us}}</ref> An informal meeting of EU transport ministers on 29 October 2018 suggested that many member states would not support the "unrealistic" timetable and that implementation could be pushed back to 2021.<ref name=bbc-Clock-ticking>{{cite news |title=Clock is ticking on EU daylight saving |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-46017347 |accessdate=30 October 2018 |work=BBC News |date=29 October 2018}}</ref>
Discussions have shown support for year-round "winter time" in e.g. Denmark, the Netherlands (UTC+1) and Finland (UTC+2) while permanent summer time was supported in Portugal (UTC+1), Poland (UTC+2) and Cyprus (UTC+3).<ref name=resistjuncker>[https://www.politico.eu/article/countries-resist-jean-claude-juncker-daylight-saving-clock-change-plan/ Countries resist Juncker’s clock change plan]</ref> Spanish opinion is split on the matter; the mainland largely favours shifting to UTC, while the [[Balearic islands]] would prefer to remain on UTC+1 and the [[Canary islands]] on UTC-1.<ref>{{cite news |title=Why Spain should turn back the clock for the last time |url=https://www.thelocal.es/20181024/why-spain-should-turn-back-the-clock-for-the-last-time |accessdate=29 October 2018 |work=The Local |date=24 October 2018 |language=en}}</ref> The United Kingdom is due to [[Brexit|leave the EU]] before the reform becomes effective; any new EU directive would apply during the transition period (if any) but thereafter the UK could choose to make its own arrangements.<ref name="bbc-20181002" /><ref>{{cite web |title=House of Lords - Subsidiarity Assessment:discontinuing seasonal changes of time - European Union Committee |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld201719/ldselect/ldeucom/200/20003.htm |website=publications.parliament.uk |accessdate=5 November 2018}}</ref> If the UK were thus to continue observing summer/winter time, [[Northern Ireland]] would have a one-hour time difference for half the year either with the rest of [[Ireland]] or with the rest of the UK, adding a further complication to the [[Irish border question]].<ref name=norniron>[https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-daylight-saving-switch-could-leave-n-ireland-out-of-step-with-rest-of-uk/ EU daylight saving switch could leave Northern Ireland out of step with rest of UK]</ref> The Irish government is to hold a public consultation on the EU proposal;<ref name="bbc-20181002">{{cite news |last1=Campbell |first1=John |title=Dublin and Belfast in separate time zones? |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-45725516 |accessdate=30 October 2018 |work=BBC News |date=2 October 2018}}</ref> {{As of|September 2018|lc=yes}}, the UK Government "has no plans" to end daylight saving.<ref>[https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/northern-ireland-wont-change-time-zone-to-suit-the-eu-say-unionists-37271919.html Northern Ireland won't change time zone to suit the EU, say unionists] {{snd}} [[Belfast Telegraph]], 1 September 2018</ref>
==Table of transition dates for European Summer Time== {{Anchor|Exact timing for the next several years}}<!--Do not remove without verifying no inlinks (renamed section)--> European Summer Time '''begins''' (clocks go forward) at 01:00 UTC on the last Sunday in March, and '''ends''' (clocks go back) at 01:00 UTC on the last Sunday in October:
{|class ="wikitable" !Start!!End |- |{{DST start date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}-4}}}}||{{DST end date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}-4}}}} |- |{{DST start date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}-3}}}}||{{DST end date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}-3}}}} |- |{{DST start date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}-2}}}}||{{DST end date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}-2}}}} |- |{{DST start date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}-1}}}}||{{DST end date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}-1}}}} |- |'''{{DST start date/EU|{{CURRENTYEAR}}}}'''||'''{{DST end date/EU|{{CURRENTYEAR}}}}''' |- |{{DST start date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}+1}}}}||{{DST end date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}+1}}}}{{notetag|If the current European Commission proposal is accepted, the October 2019 clock change could be the last one.}} |- |{{DST start date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}+2}}}}||{{DST end date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}+2}}}} |- |{{DST start date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}+3}}}}||{{DST end date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}+3}}}} <!--|- |{{DST start date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}+4}}}}||{{DST end date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}+4}}}} |- |{{DST start date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}+5}}}}||{{DST end date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}+5}}}} |- |{{DST start date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}+6}}}}||{{DST end date/EU|{{#expr:{{CURRENTYEAR}}+6}}}} --> |} A formula which can be used to calculate the '''beginning''' of European Summer Time is:
'''Sunday (31 − ((((5 × ''y'') ÷ 4) + 4) mod 7)) March at 01:00 UTC'''
The corresponding formula for the '''end''' of European Summer Time is:
'''Sunday (31 − ((((5 × ''y'') ÷ 4) + 1) mod 7)) October at 01:00 UTC'''
where ''y'' is the year, and ''a'' [[Modulo operation|mod]] ''b'' is ''b'' times the fractional part of ''a''/''b''. These formulae are valid until 2099.<ref>Attributed to Robert H. van Gent. [http://webexhibits.org/daylightsaving/i.html "Daylight Saving Time: About this exhibit"]</ref>
==Double Summer Time== "Double Summer Time" (two hours ahead of local winter time) has been observed on some occasions, notably in 1921, 1941-45 and 1947. See: * [[British Double Summer Time]] ([[UTC+02:00]]) * [[Central European Midsummer Time]] ([[UTC+03:00]]) * [[Moscow Midsummer Time]] ([[UTC+05:00]])
==Countries not switching to and from summer time== There are four countries that do not use summer time, but keep the same time all year.
Some may be thought of as using "permanent" summer time, since they use time zones allocated to regions further east than themselves. Belarus explicitly decided to stay permanently on (what it formerly called) summer time after 2011.
Spain, France, Belgium, and the Netherlands may also be thought of as observing "summer time" throughout the winter, and "double-summer time" during summer, because of their position to the west of the central European time zone.
*{{flag|Belarus}} switched to summer time in Spring 2011 and did not switch back, and is now observing [[UTC+03:00|UTC+3]] all year round. The midpoint of Belarus has longitude 28°E (corresponds to UTC+1.8). *{{flag|Iceland}} observes UTC all year round despite being at longitudes (13°W-24°W) which would indicate [[UTC-01:00|UTC-1]]. Iceland's high latitude (the Reykjavík region, home to nearly two-thirds of the country's people, is at [[64th parallel north|64°N]]) means that sunset and sunrise times change by many hours over the year, and the effect of changing the clock by one hour would, in comparison, be small. *{{flag|Russia}} used "permanent summer time" from 2011 to 2014. In October 2014 Russia changed permanently back to standard time ([[UTC+03:00]] in the country's west, including Moscow), setting the clocks back one hour at the same time as other European countries did.<ref>{{cite news|title=Russia set to turn back the clocks with daylight-saving time shift|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/01/russia-state-duma-daylight-saving-time-summer|accessdate=25 October 2014|publisher=The Guardian|date=1 July 2014}}</ref> *{{flag|Turkey}} decided to stop daylight saving time in September 2016, but to stay in on [[UTC+03:00|UTC+3]] throughout the year rather than switching back to its original time [[UTC+02:00|UTC+2]].
==Local observations== In most of Europe, the word ''Summer'' is added to the name of each European [[time zone]] during this period: thus, in the [[UTC+01:00]] time zone, [[Central European Time]] becomes [[Central European Summer Time]] ([[UTC+02:00]]).
==={{flagu|Austria}}=== [[Austria]] used summer time in 1916–1918, 1920, 1940–1948 (as part of [[Nazi Germany]] between 1940–1945) and since 1980.
===={{flagu|Austria-Hungary}}==== [[Austria-Hungary]] used summer time during World War I in 1916, 1917 and 1918, in line with the [[German Empire]].
==={{flagu|Bulgaria}}=== Summer time was introduced in Bulgaria in 1979 by a regulation of the Bulgarian Council of Ministers. Bulgaria observes the European Union rules for summer time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.novinite.com/view_news.php?id=113965|title=Bulgaria Turns Clocks to Daylight Saving Time March 28 - Novinite.com - Sofia News Agency|date=|website=novinite.com}}</ref>
==={{flagu|Czech Republic}}=== In the [[Kingdom of Bohemia]] summer time was used for three seasons during World War I, from 1916 to 1918, while part of the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian Empire]].
During World War II, when the [[Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia]] became a [[de facto]] part of [[Nazi Germany]], summer time was used from 1940. In 1940/1941 and 1941/1942, the summer time was kept continuously even during the winter.
[[Czech Republic]] continued to use summer time after the [[dissolution of Czechoslovakia]] in 1993.
===={{flagu|Czechoslovakia}}==== [[Czechoslovakia]] used summer time from 1945 to 1949 and from 1979 to 1992. In winter 1946/1947 (from 1 December to 23 February), [[winter time (Czechoslovakia)|winter time]] (CET−01:00) was used.
==={{flagu|Denmark}}=== Summer time has been observed in [[Denmark]] since 1980. A national association against summer time (Landsforeningen mod Sommertid) exists,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ikkesommertid.info/|title=Landsforeningen mod Sommertid|accessdate=2007-10-27|language=Danish}}</ref> which celebrated the EU commission preliminary decision in August 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bt.dk/samfund/formand-jubler-over-eu-udmelding-sa-skal-champagnen-flyde-i-stride-stromme |title=Formand jubler over EU-udmelding: 'Så skal champagnen flyde i stride strømme'] (translation: The chairman is delighted with EU announcement: "The champagne will flow in steady flow") |date=31 August 2018}}</ref>
==={{flagu|Estonia}}=== In [[Estonia]] summer time was not used in 1989–1996 and 2000–2001. It was used under Soviet rule in 1981–1988.
==={{flagu|Faroe Islands}}=== The Faroe Islands observes summer time since 1981.<ref>[[tz database]]</ref> The islands has never been part of the EU, so the decision to observe summer time was its own.
==={{flagu|Finland}}=== In Finland, summer time has been used on a regular basis since 1981.
[[Initiative#Finland|A citizens' initiative]] to abolish daylight saving time was signed by 70,000 Finnish citizens. It was presented to the Finnish parliament in June 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://yle.fi/uutiset/osasto/news/citizens_initiative_to_dump_daylight_saving_time_heads_to_finnish_lawmakers/9657273|title=Citizens' initiative to dump Daylight Saving Time heads to Finnish lawmakers|author=|date=|website=yle.fi}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-finland-eu-daylightsaving/finland-wants-eu-to-give-up-daylight-saving-time-idUSKBN1CV2OE|title=Finland wants EU to give up daylight saving time|first=Reuters|last=Editorial|date=|website=reuters.com}}</ref>
==={{flagu|France}} and {{flagu|Monaco}}=== From 1923 until the Second World War, France and Monaco observed summer time from the last Saturday in March until the first Saturday in October. During the Second World War France also observed summer time. However, after the war the practice was abandoned (since the country changed time zones instituting ''de facto'' permanent summer time). In 1975, summer time was reimplemented because of the [[1973 oil crisis|oil crisis]].<ref name=Poulle>{{cite journal|last=Poulle|first=Yvonne|title=La France à l'heure allemande|journal=Bibliothèque de l'école des chartes|year=1999|volume=157|issue=2|pages=493–502|language=French|url=http://www.persee.fr/articleAsPDF/bec_0373-6237_1999_num_157_2_450989/article_bec_0373-6237_1999_num_157_2_450989.pdf|accessdate=11 January 2012|doi=10.3406/bec.1999.450989}}</ref>
Since GMT (now UTC) is France's "natural" time zone, its use of UTC+1 in winter can be seen as a form of [[daylight saving time]], while its use of Central European Summer Time (UTC+2) in summer can be seen as a form of "double summer time".<ref>{{cite web|last=Thorsen|first=Steffen|title=France and Spain kicks into "Double Summer Time"|url=http://www.timeanddate.com/news/time/france-spain-summer-time.html|publisher=Time and Date.com|accessdate=11 January 2012}}</ref>
France and Monaco follow EU rules regarding the start and end times and dates for summer time.
==={{flagu|Germany}}=== Summer time was first introduced during [[World War I]] by the [[German Empire]] from 1916 to 1918. After the end of the war and the proclamation of the [[Weimar Republic]] in November 1918, summer time ceased to be observed. Summer time was reintroduced in 1940, during [[World War II]], to try to save energy for the [[war economy]]. After the defeat of Germany, summer time was retained by the occupation powers. In 1945, [[Berlin]] and the Soviet Occupation Zone even observed [[Central European Midsummer Time]] (''Mitteleuropäische Hochsommerzeit'', ''MEHSZ''; [[UTC+03:00]]): in 1947, all of Germany switched to midsummer time from 11 May to 29 June. After the [[Federal Republic of Germany|Federal Republic]] (West Germany) and the [[German Democratic Republic]] (East Germany) were established in 1949, summer time again ceased to be observed in 1950.
In 1978, [[West Germany]] decided to reintroduce summer time, following the example set by several neighbouring states in the aftermath of the [[1973 oil crisis]]. However, it only came into effect in 1980, after West and [[East Germany]] reached an agreement to observe summer time simultaneously from the last Sunday in March (02:00 CET) to the last Sunday in September (03:00 CEST). Thus both German states observed the same time until the [[German reunification]] in 1990, after which the reunified Germany retained the laws and thus also the Time Act (''Zeitgesetz'') of West Germany.
After 1980, West and East Germany; since 1991 reunified Germany: [[Central European Summer Time]].<ref>[http://www.ptb.de/cms/en/fachabteilungen/abt4/fb-44/ag-441/realisation-of-legal-time-in-germany/dst-and-midsummer-dst-in-germany-until-1979.html DST and midsummer DST in Germany until 1979], Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt. (2010)</ref>
[[Büsingen am Hochrhein]], a small exclave, entirely surrounded by Swiss territory, did not implement summer time in 1980 but observed the same time as Switzerland; thus there was a one hour time difference between this village and the rest of [[Germany]]. The zone [[Europe/Busingen]]{{clarify|date=August 2018}} was created in the 2013a release of the [[tz database]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mm.icann.org/pipermail/tz-announce/2013-March/000009.html |title=tzcode2013a and tzdata2013a available |first=Paul |last=Eggert |publisher=[http://mm.icann.org/pipermail/tz-announce/ tz-announce] |date=2013-03-02}}</ref> because since the [[Unix time]] epoch in 1970, Büsingen am Hochrhein has shared clocks with [[Zurich]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://article.gmane.org/gmane.comp.time.tz/4765 |title=New zone for DE, split from Europe/Berlin |first=Arthur David |last=Olson |publisher=gmane.comp.time.tz |date=2012-03-03}}</ref>
Germany follows the [[European Union|EU]] rules regarding the start and end times and dates for summer time.
==={{flagu|Greenland}}=== {{see also|Daylight saving time in the Americas#Greenland}} [[Greenland]] observes Summer Time simultaneously with Europe. Summer Time thus begins at 00:00 [[Time in Denmark|East Greenland Time]] on Sunday, and 22:00 West Greenland Time on Saturday, and ends at 01:00 EGST on Sunday and 23:00 WGST on Saturday. It was introduced in 1980 when Greenland was legally a part of Denmark without local rule. The most other EU [[Overseas countries and territories]] do not observe summer time. Exceptions, based on company decisions, are the northeastern coast around [[Danmarkshavn]] (UTC year-round) for [[Thule Air Base]] (which follows [[Atlantic time zone|Atlantic Time]] and observes [[Daylight saving time in Canada|in accordance with US and Canadian rules]])
==={{flagu|Hungary}}=== Summer time was first introduced in Hungary in 1916, and it was observed until 1919. After that, summer time was in use between 1941–1949 and 1954–1957. Summer time has been in use again since 1980 and follows EU rules.
==={{flagu|Iceland}}=== [[Iceland]] uses UTC but has not used summer time since April 1968. From 1908 to 1968 Iceland used UTC−1. Summer time was used in 1917-1919, 1921 and 1939-1967.
==={{flagu|Ireland}}=== {{Further information|Time in Ireland}}
In [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], Summer Time, known as Irish Standard Time (IST) is observed during Summer (March to October). IST is sometimes mistaken for "Irish Summer Time", though this is incorrect.
==={{flagu|Italy}}, {{flagu|San Marino}}, and {{flagu|Vatican City}}=== Summer time is known as "ora legale" (literally "legal hour", referencing the fact that it's mandated by law) in [[Italy]], and it has been adopted and abolished several times: it was observed from 1916 to 1920 and between 1944 and 1948. A law was approved in 1965 that took effect the following year, and made the application of summer time mandatory in the whole country. Since 1996, it has been coordinated with the [[European Union]]. [[San Marino]] and [[Vatican City State]] share land borders solely with Italy and observe the same time as in Italy.
==={{flagu|Norway}}=== In Norway, summer time was observed in 1916, 1940–45, and 1959-65. The arrangement was controversial, and in 1965 the Norwegian parliament ([[Stortinget]]) voted to discontinue the practice. Their neighbour, Sweden, did not use it.
However, in 1980 summer time was reintroduced (together with Sweden and Denmark), and since at least 2002 Norway has followed the European Union in this matter.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.forskning.no/Artikler/2002/oktober/1035454427.68|title=Hva er sommertid?|work=Forskning.no|accessdate=2007-10-27|language=Norwegian}}</ref>
==={{flagu|Poland}}=== In Poland, "the summer time" was observed in the following years: * 1918 * 1946 - 1949 * 1957 - 1964 * 1977 - (still) In the years 1979 - 1995 the last day of summer time was the last Saturday of September. In 1996 it was changed to the last Saturday of October, to synchronise with other countries of the EU.
==={{flagu|Portugal}}=== In Portugal, summer time (locally known by "Hora de Verão") was introduced in 1916. In the years 1922, 1923, 1925, 1930, 1933 and from 1967 to 1975 summer time was not applied.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oal.ul.pt/download/dadosoutros/HoraLegaldesde1911.pdf|title=Hora Legal desde 1911 (Legal Time since 1911)|language=Portuguese|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316015149/http://www.oal.ul.pt/download/dadosoutros/HoraLegaldesde1911.pdf|archivedate=2012-03-16|df=}}</ref> For many years the official time in the [[Madeira Islands]] was one hour earlier than that in [[Lisbon]], and the [[Azores Islands]] were two hours behind. Today, in the Madeira Islands the official time is the same as that of Lisbon, and in the Azores Islands it is one hour behind Lisbon. The start and end dates for summer time in Portugal follow the pattern in the rest of the EU: the last Sunday in March to the last Sunday in October.
==={{flagu|Romania}}=== Summer time in Romania (locally known by "Ora de Vară") was originally introduced in 1932 (between 22 May and 2 October). Between 1933 and 1940 summer time started on the first Sunday in April and ended on the first Sunday in October. Summer time was abandoned in 1941 and reintroduced in 1979. Until 1996, with few exceptions, summer time started at the end of March and ended at the end of September. Since 1997, it has started in the last Sunday in March and ended on the last Sunday in October, in accordance with European Union rules.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.astro-urseanu.ro/ora_vara.html|title=Observatorul Astronomic - Ora de vara|accessdate=2008-11-15|language=Romanian}} Contains tables with all historical summer time start and end dates since 1932.</ref>
==={{flagu|Russia}}=== {{Further information|Time in Russia}} A decree of the [[Russian Provisional Government]] introduced summer time ({{lang-ru|летнее время}}) in [[Russia]] on 30 June 1917, and clocks moved one hour forward. A [[Soviet Decrees|decree]] of the [[Sovnarkom|Soviet government]] led to the abandonment of this system five months later: clocks moved one hour back again on 28 December.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeanddate.com/time/zone/russia/moscow?year=1916|title=Time Zone & Clock Changes 1900-1924 in Moscow, Russia|author=|date=|website=www.timeanddate.com}}</ref>
From 1930, [[Decree time]] had the effect of imposing year-round time-zone advances in the Soviet Union.
A decision of the [[Council of Ministers (Soviet Union)|Council of Ministers of the USSR]] reintroduced summer time in the [[USSR]] ([[Moscow Summer Time]], for example) on 1 April 1981, and its practice continued into post-Soviet times until 2011. The changeover dates in [[Russia]] were the same as for other European countries, but clocks were moved forward or back at 02:00 local time in all zones. Thus in Moscow (local time = UTC+3 in winter, UTC+4 in summer), summer time commenced at 02:00 UTC on the day before the last Sunday in March, and ended at 03:00 UTC on the day before the last Sunday in October. (Note that "day before the last Sunday" is not the same as "the last Saturday" in a month where the last day is a Saturday.)
[[File:December 23, 2013 in Brateyevo (Moscow) at 9.06.jpg|thumbnail|right|Night black sky at 9:06 am (UTC+4) on 23 December 2013 in Moscow]] On 8 February 2011, Russian President [[Dmitry Medvedev]] announced cancellation of biannual clock changes in Russia in favor of a permanent switch to summer time. An hour was added in March 2011 for the last time, and clocks did not move back again. At the same time some of Russia's time zones were consolidated.<ref name=Gessen/> After this reform many Russian cities had a "standard time" two hours more than would be suggested by their "astronomical time" (because the original standard time was already ahead of astronomical time in many areas).<ref name=Gessen/>
During his [[Russian presidential election, 2012 | 2012 election campaign]], [[Vladimir Putin]] proposed re-introducing summer time, as some workers had complained about not seeing any daylight during the winter, since the sun had not risen when they went to work.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.timeanddate.com/news/time/russia-daylight-saving-promise.html|title= Russian prime minister promises daylight saving time|publisher= Time and Date.com|date= 8 February 2012|accessdate= 4 January 2013}}</ref> According to a report in the ''International Herald Tribune'', Russian citizens remembered the winter of 2011-12 as the "darkest winter on record" as a result of the time change.<ref name=Gessen/> However, Putin later said it would be up to then Prime Minister Medvedev's cabinet to decide how to proceed with a seasonal time shift, and it decided to stay with the 2011 policy.<ref name=Gessen> {{cite web|last= Gessen|first= Masha|title = Will Russia Turn Back the Clock? |url = http://latitude.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/10/01/will-russia-restore-daylight-saving-time/ |work = Latitude: Views from Around the World|publisher= International Herald Tribune |accessdate = 4 January 2013|date= 1 October 2012 }}</ref>
On 26 October 2014 Russia permanently returned to "winter" time.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/blogs-news-from-elsewhere-28423647 BBC Russia: Putin abolishes "daylight savings" time change] </ref><ref>[http://www.rg.ru/2014/07/22/vremya-site.html Российская Газета: Президент вернул "зимнее время"] </ref>
==={{flagu|Slovakia}}=== [[Slovakia]] used summer time (locally known as "Letný čas") in 1916, 1917 and 1918, as part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, then in the early 1940s, as part of Nazi Germany and annually since 1979, as part of Czechoslovakia.
After several years, Slovakia established the rule that summer time begins in the last weekend of March (during the night from Saturday to Sunday) and ends in the last weekend of September. {{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}
After [[dissolution of Czechoslovakia]] in 1993, Slovakia continued to use summer time. Since 1996, summer time has been prolonged about one month so it lasts until the last weekend in October, in accordance with European Union rules.
==={{flagu|Slovenia}}=== Summer time in Slovenia (locally known as "Poletni čas") was introduced on 16 November 1982 when it was one of the Yugoslavia republics. Same law was valid until 1996 when the end of summer time was changed from first Sunday in October to last Sunday in October. In 2006, the European Union standard was adopted and is still used today.
==={{flagu|Sweden}}=== In [[Sweden]] summer time was originally introduced on 15 May 1916. It proved unpopular, and on 30 September in the same year, Sweden returned to year-round standard time. This continued for more than half a century.
On 6 April 1980, Sweden again introduced summer time, and since then summer time has been observed every summer in Sweden. Except for the introduction year 1980, summer time has always started on the last Sunday in March. It ended on the last Sunday in September during the years 1980-1995, and has ended on the last Sunday in October since 1996, following a unification of start/end dates of summer time within the [[European Union|EU]] as well as in several European countries then outside the EU.
The transit authority [[Västtrafik]] changes its clocks at 04:00, so that the last tram that leaves around 3:30 actually goes 2:30 on the last weekend of October for those who have changed their clocks at the legal time.<ref>[https://www.facebook.com/Vasttrafik/posts/388878481135963 Natten mellan lördag och söndag går vi över till sommartid] (Swedish)</ref> The public transport company [[Storstockholms Lokaltrafik|SL]] changes their clocks at the legal time, and runs extra departures during the October transition hour.<ref>[http://www.svd.se/nyheter/stockholm/sommartid-blir-vintertid-aven-i-sl-trafiken_535945.svd Sommartid blir vintertid - även i SL-trafiken] (Swedish)</ref>
==={{flagu|Switzerland}} and {{flagu|Liechtenstein}}=== The last country in Europe to adopt summer time, in 1981, was [[Switzerland]], even though summer time had been rejected by 52.1% of voters in a federal referendum in 1978.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.admin.ch/ch/f/pore/va/19780528/det283.html|title=Votation No|first=Chancellerie fédérale|last=ChF|date=|website=www.admin.ch}}</ref> Since 1996 Swiss summer time follows EU regulations. It had been in use in 1941 and 1942.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.suedostschweiz.ch/politik/seit-30-jahren-sommerzeit-der-schweiz|title=Seit 30 Jahren Sommerzeit in der Schweiz|author=|date=|website=www.suedostschweiz.ch}}</ref> [[Liechtenstein]] observes the same time as Switzerland. The German village of [[Büsingen am Hochrhein]], a small exclave, entirely surrounded by Swiss territory, also observes the same time as in Switzerland; it did not implement summer time in 1980, and observed the same time as Switzerland, so that there was a one hour time difference between this village and the rest of [[Germany]].
==={{flagu|Turkey}}=== Summer time was introduced in [[Turkey]] in 1947, but suspended from 1965 to 1972. Since 1974, Turkey follows European Summer Time.
In 2008, the Turkish Ministry of Energy proposed that Turkey should abolish summer time while at the same time switching to GMT +2.5, originally from 2009 onwards, but when this appeared infeasible, to start in 2011,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.worldtimezone.com/dst_news/dst_news_turkey02.html |title=Turkey to abandon daylight saving time in 2011|newspaper=[[Turkish Daily News]] |publisher=Worldtimezone.com |date=19 August 2008 |accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref> the plan has not been heard of since.
For the year 2011, Turkey switched to European Summer Time at 3:00 am (03:00) on Monday 28 March, one day later than the rest of Europe, to avoid disrupting the national university entrance examinations held on 27 March.<ref>{{cite news |title=Turkey switches to summer time one day later |url=http://www.worldbulletin.net/?aType=haber&ArticleID=70872 |publisher=World Bulletin |date=10 March 2011 |accessdate=2011-03-12}}</ref>
Once again, for the year 2014, Turkey switched to European Summer Time at 3:00 am (03:00) on Monday 31 March, one day later than the rest of Europe, to avoid disrupting the [[Turkish local elections, 2014|local elections]] held on 30 March.<ref>{{cite news |title=Turkey's election delays summertime |url=http://www.worldbulletin.net/turkey/131791/turkeys-election-delays-summertime |publisher=World Bulletin |date=23 March 2014 |accessdate=2014-03-30}}</ref>
In 2015, Turkey delayed the switch from European Summer Time by 2 weeks, to 4:00 am (04:00) on Sunday 8 November, two weeks later than the rest of Europe, due to the calling of a [[Turkish general election, November 2015|snap general election]] on Sunday, 1 November.<ref>{{cite news |title=End of Daylight Saving Time delayed in Turkey |url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/end-of-daylight-saving-time-delayed-in-turkey.aspx?pageID=238&nID=89163&NewsCatID=341 |publisher=Hürriyet |date=30 September 2015 |accessdate=2015-10-07}}</ref>
In 2016, Turkey scrapped winter time, by switching to New Turkey Time. This means permanent UTC+3, which was used during summer time in Turkey. The switch was on 12:00 am (00:00) on Thursday 8 September, in reality stopping switches between summer and winter time.<ref>{{cite news |title=Scraps Winter Time delayed In Turkey |url=http://www.timeanddate.com/news/time/turkey-scraps-dst-2016.html |publisher=Hürriyet |date=8 September 2016 |accessdate=2016-09-08}}</ref>
==={{flagu|Ukraine}}=== Summer time was introduced in [[Ukraine]] in the early 1980s; from 1981 till 1989 this was [[Moscow Summer Time]]; since 1992 [[Eastern European Summer Time]] has been used.<ref name="Kyivwintertimeisgone"/><ref name="Kyivwintertimeisback"/>
On 20 September 2011 the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament) voted not to return from Eastern European Summer Time to [[Eastern European Time]].<ref name="Kyivwintertimeisgone">[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/113166/ Ukraine cancels use of daylight saving time], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (20 September 2011)</ref><ref>[http://www.worldtimezone.com/dst_news/dst_news_ukraine04.html Deputies cancelled the winter time], WorldTimeZone.com (20 September 2011)</ref> This change would have had the effect of moving Ukraine into the [[Further-eastern European Time]] zone [[UTC+03:00]] along with Belarus and western Russia (which do not observe summer time). However, on 18 October 2011 the Parliament canceled these plans and the country returned to [[Eastern European Time]] as scheduled.<ref name="Kyivwintertimeisback">[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/115146/ Ukraine to return to standard time on 30 Oct (updated)], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (18 October 2011)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/115182/ Ukraine cancels plan to drop winter time change], ''[[Kyiv Post]]'' (18 October 2011)</ref> 295 MPs voted in favour out of 349 registered MPs.<ref name="Kyivwintertimeisback"/>
Crimea and regions of eastern Ukraine under the control of separatist militants observe [[Further-eastern European Time]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tass.ru/en/world/756540|title=DPR and LPR switch over to Moscow time|publisher=[[ITAR TASS]]|date=26 October 2014|accessdate=15 August 2015}}</ref>
==={{flagu|United Kingdom}}=== {{main article|British Summer Time}}
In the [[United Kingdom]] local time during this period is known as [[British Summer Time]] (BST) ([[UTC+01:00]]) while local time during the rest of the year is normally referred to as [[Greenwich Mean Time|Greenwich Mean Time (GMT)]]. More generally British Summer Time is part of [[Western European Summer Time]].
Legislation: Summer Time Act 1916; Summer Time Act 1922; Time (Ireland) Act, 1916; Summer Time Act, 1925; Emergency Powers (Defence) Act, 1939; The Summer Time Order 1964; The Summer Time Order 1967; Summer Time Act 1972; The Summer Time Order 1997; The Summer Time Order 2002.<ref name=DSTUK>{{cite web|url=http://www.webexhibits.org/daylightsaving/uk.html|title=Full text - Daylight Saving Time - United Kingdom Law - The Summer Time Order 1997|author=|date=|website=www.webexhibits.org}}</ref>
Since 1996 all clocks in the European Union, of which the UK is a member state, have changed on same dates and at the same time, 01:00 GMT.<ref name="wwp">[http://wwp.greenwichmeantime.com/time-zone/europe/uk/time/british-summer-time/ British Summer Time], wwp.greenwichmeantime.com</ref> *British Summer Time starts: Last Sunday in March *British Summer Time ends: Last Sunday in October *British Summer Time clocks change at 01:00 (1.00 am) Greenwich Mean Time (GMT).
The [[Channel Islands]] and [[Isle of Man]] observe the same time as the UK mainland.
